metadata.case_name: Appellant Company v. Income-tax Officer, Porbander

facts.text: Prior to 1949, no income-tax in Porbander, part of State of Saurashtra.
In 1949, Saurashtra Income-tax Ordinance promulgated, applicable to State of Saurashtra.
From 1950, Saurashtra part of Union of India, Indian Income-tax Act applicable via Finance Act of 1950.
Appellant assessed for accounting year 1949 (assessment year 1950-51), depreciation allowed under s. 10(2)(vi) Rs. 3,43,869.
Appellant assessed for 1952-53 and 1953-54; for 1953-54, original depreciation Rs. 3,48,105 per order dated June 30, 1955.
On August 8, 1955, appellant applied for rectification under s. 35 pointing out mistakes in depreciation calculations.
ITO order dated February 27, 1956, rectified Written Down Value, determined depreciation Rs. 1,94,074; unabsorbed depreciation reduced from Rs. 2,31,944 to Rs. 83,295, set off against 1954-55 income.
On February 29, 1956, ITO passed provisional assessment orders for 1954-55 and 1955-56 using same Written Down Value as 1953-54.
ITO order dated May 18, 1956, explained calculations based on Saurashtra Ordinance and Indian Income-tax Act, citing various authorities.
No written notice of intended rectification given under s. 35 read with s. 63.
On March 9, 1956, appellant protested ITO order, alleging excess of jurisdiction, requested cancellation.
ITO replied on same date that order was correct.
On April 16, 1956, appellant filed petition in Bombay High Court under Arts. 226 and 227 to quash s. 35 order.
Bombay High Court dismissed petition on November 26, 1957, on grounds of alternative remedy under s. 33A and on merits.
ITO affidavit: Depreciation discussed with appellant's Secretary Shri Ganatra; no written notice but opportunity given, calculations supplied on 21-2-1956.
Depreciation in 1943-44: Rs. 1,91,224 (non-resident).
1944-45 and 1945-46: No assessable income in British India.
1947-48: Sales at Porbander, no collection in British India, tax Rs. 43-11As.
1948-49: Sales Rs. 38,656, total income Rs. 9,326.
1949-50: Depreciation allowed Rs. 3,66,925 under Ordinance.

legal_issues.text: Whether no notice as required under s. 35 was given to the appellant
Whether there was no record on the basis of which the rectification in the Written Down Value could be made
Whether there was no mistake apparent from the record

petitioner_arguments.text: No notice under s. 35 given; ITO exceeded jurisdiction by preparing new statements prejudicial to company without prior notice.
No record for rectification of Written Down Value; s. 35 not for corrections in WDV, appropriate is s. 34 for excessive depreciation.
No mistake apparent from the record; recalculation not rectification.
Saurashtra Ordinance provisions cannot form basis for WDV under s. 10(5)(b) after Act applicable.
Explanation to Removal of Difficulties Order ultra vires, promulgated under wrong section.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s. 60A of the Act, s. 12 Finance Act 1950; S. V. Naik v. CIT; CIT v. D. B. R. Mills Ltd.

respondent_arguments.text: Art. 226 discretionary; adequate remedy under s. 33A.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Art. 226; K. S. Rashid & Son v. Income-tax Investigation Commission

respondent_arguments.text: Matter discussed with appellant's representative; reasonable opportunity given though no written notice; no enhancement or refund reduction.
WDV not final, can be redetermined in subsequent years.
Mistake apparent from record; ITO can examine whole record including past calculations.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s. 35; CIT v. Khem Chand Ramdas (PC); Sidhramappa v. CIT; M. K. Venkatachalam v. Bombay Dyeing

court_reasoning.text: No interference with High Court's discretion needed as case decided on merits; notice under s. 35 not rigid if reasonable opportunity given and no detriment like enhancement.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Assessee knew of proceedings, discussed with representative; calculations supplied.

court_reasoning.text: Record includes all proceedings on which assessment based; ITO can check past calculations for mistake apparent from record.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Mistake in depreciation calculation apparent upon review of records from 1943-44 onwards.

court_reasoning.text: Recalculation of WDV and depreciation is rectification of mistake apparent from record under s. 35, not limited to current year.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Cites precedents allowing rectification for errors in law or fact apparent from record.

court_reasoning.text: WDV determination under s. 35 not final or res judicata for future years.
court_reasoning.key_observation: ITO can determine actual cost and past allowances each year.

holdings.text: No written notice under s. 35 not fatal if reasonable opportunity given and no enhancement/refund reduction.
ITO entitled to rectify mistake apparent from entire record, including past years' calculations for WDV.
Mistake in depreciation calculation was apparent from record; s. 35 applicable for such rectification.

precedents_cited.case_name: K. S. Rashid & Son v. Income-tax Investigation Commission
precedents_cited.relevance: Art. 226 discretionary remedy if alternative available.

precedents_cited.case_name: Karnani Industrial Bank Ltd. v. CIT, West Bengal
precedents_cited.relevance: ITO can redetermine WDV and original cost in subsequent years; no res judicata.

precedents_cited.case_name: S. V. Naik v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Petitioner contention on ultra vires explanation; no opinion expressed.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. D. B. R. Mills Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Petitioner contention on ultra vires explanation; no opinion expressed.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Khem Chand Ramdas
precedents_cited.relevance: s. 35 applies to mistake apparent from record including subsequent orders affecting it.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sidhramappa Andannappa Manvi v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Tribunal can rectify mistake under s. 35 and pass consequential order.

precedents_cited.case_name: M. K. Venkatachalam v. Bombay Dyeing and Manufacturing Co. Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Mistake of law apparent from record rectifiable under s. 35, even from retrospective amendment.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs depreciation, WDV calculation, rectification of mistakes apparent from record.

statutes_cited.name: Saurashtra Income-tax Ordinance, 1949
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for initial WDV calculations before Indian Act applied.

statutes_cited.name: Finance Act, 1950
statutes_cited.relevance: Extended Act to Part B States; empowered Removal of Difficulties Order.

statutes_cited.name: Taxation Laws (Part B States) Removal of Difficulties Order, 1950
statutes_cited.relevance: Computation of aggregate depreciation and WDV from Part B State laws.

outcome.summary: Appeal by special leave dismissed; High Court order upheld. ITO's rectification under s. 35 valid despite no written notice, as opportunity given and mistake apparent from record. No finality to WDV determination.

key_quotes.text: "the record does not mean only the order of assessment but it comprises all proceedings on which the assessment order is based"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines scope of 'record' under s. 35 for rectification.

key_quotes.text: "A mistake contemplated by this section is not one which is to be discovered as a result of an argument but it is open to the Income-tax Officer to examine the record including the evidence"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Clarifies nature of 'mistake apparent from the record'.

key_quotes.text: "If a mistake of fact apparent from the record of the assessment order can be rectified under s. 35 we see no reason why a mistake of law which is glaring and obvious cannot be similarly rectified."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Extends s. 35 to mistakes of law (from Venkatachalam case).
